content.text: Measure the time \(t\) taken for 20 oscillations. Do **not** remove the mass from the spring
Record \(t\) in Table 1.1
Calculate the period \(T\) of the oscillations
Record your answer in Table 1.1
Suggest how the procedure can be improved to increase the accuracy of the result
Calculate a value \(k_{1}\) for the spring constant of the spring
Use the equation shown. Give your answer to an appropriate number of significant figures
Method 2
Attach the spring to the clamp, as shown in Fig. 1.1
Suspend a mass \(m = 500 \text{g}\) from the spring
Pull the mass down a small distance (2–3 cm) from its rest position and release it
The mass oscillates up and down
The period \(T\) of the oscillations is the time taken for one oscillation
One complete oscillation of the mass is shown in Fig. 1.2
With the \(500\mathrm{g}\) mass still suspended from the spring, measure the stretched length \(l\) of the spring in centimetres to the nearest \(0.1\mathrm{cm}\)
Do not include the loops at the ends of the spring in your measurement
Record \(l\) in Table 1.2

Carefully remove the \(100\mathrm{g}\) masses from the mass hanger, one at a time, and repeat the procedure in **(b)**(i) for \(m = 400\mathrm{g}\) , \(300\mathrm{g}\) , \(200\mathrm{g}\) and \(100\mathrm{g}\)
Record each value of \(l\) in Table 1.2
Plot a graph of \(l / \text{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(m / \text{g}\) (x-axis). Start your axes at the origin \((0, 0)\)
Draw the best-fit line
m/g
Determine the gradient \(G\) of your line. Show all working and indicate on the graph the values you use
An estimated value \(k_{2}\) for the spring constant of the spring can be calculated using the equation
Calculate \(k_{2}\) using your value of \(G\) from (b)(iv) and the equation shown
Two quantities can be considered to be equal within the limits of experimental accuracy if their values are within \(10\%\) of each other
Compare your values of \(k_{1}\) from (a)(iv) and \(k_{2}\) from (b)(v)
State whether your results indicate that the values can be considered to be equal
Support your statement with a calculation
[Total: 13]
In this experiment, you will measure the spring constant \(k\) of a spring by two different methods
The spring constant \(k\) of a spring is a measure of how difficult the spring is to stretch
**Method 1**
Close the switch
Record the voltmeter reading \(V\) in the first row of Table 2.1
Record the ammeter reading \(I\) in the first row of Table 2.1
Open the switch
Use a spare connecting lead to connect the \(3\Omega\) resistor in series with the \(10\Omega\) resistor between terminals X and Y, as shown in Fig. 2.2
Record the voltmeter reading \(V\) in the second row of Table 2.1
Record the ammeter reading \(I\) in the second row of Table 2.1
Open the switch
Connect the \(7\Omega\) , \(10\Omega\) and \(3\Omega\) resistors in series between X and Y. Repeat the procedure in (b) with this arrangement of resistors
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the diode for each pair of readings of \(V\) and \(I\) from Table 2.1
Use the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
Record your answers in Table 2.1
the potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) across the diode
the resistance \(R\) of the diode
As the resistance between terminals X and Y is increased, the current in the circuit changes
Use your results in Table 2.1 to state the relationship between the current in the circuit and:
A student attempts to set up the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1. The student finds that the ammeter does not give a reading when the circuit is complete. The ammeter is not broken
Suggest what the student may have done incorrectly while setting up the circuit
Name a single device that can be used to control the current in the circuit instead of adding extra resistors in series
Draw the electrical symbol for the device
name of device
electrical symbol
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance \(R\) of a diode using the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1
Fig. 3.2 is on page 11 of your question paper
- On Fig. 3.2, draw a normal to the line \(\mathbf{XY}\) at the point \(\mathbf{E}\). Extend your normal above and below \(\mathbf{XY}\)
Measure the angle \(\theta\) between \(\mathbf{FE}\) and the normal
- Extend the line \(\mathbf{FE}\) until it almost meets the right-hand side of the page and label the end of the line \(\mathbf{G}\)
Place the block on Fig. 3.2 with one of the long sides of the block along the line \(\mathbf{XY}\). The top left-hand corner of the block must be at \(\mathbf{A}\), as shown in Fig. 3.1
Fig. 3.1
On Fig. 3.2, draw around the outline of the block
Remove the block
Label the outline of the block \(\mathbf{ABCD}\), as shown in Fig. 3.1
Mark the point where the normal crosses side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block with the letter \(\mathbf{H}\)
Replace the block
Switch on the lamp
- Position the illuminated slit so that a ray of light passes along the line \(\mathbf{FE}\) towards \(\mathbf{E}\)
On Fig. 3.2, mark and label with small crosses (x) two points on the ray that leaves side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block
Choose the position of the points so that the direction of the ray leaving the block can be accurately drawn.
- Remove the block
Draw a straight line through the two crosses to meet side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block
Label the point where the line meets \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{J}\) and label the other end of the line \(\mathbf{K}\)
Draw a straight line from \(\mathbf{E}\) to \(\mathbf{J}\). This shows the path of the ray of light through the block
Suggest one source of inaccuracy in this experiment, even if it is carried out very carefully
The measurement of a quantity is reproducible if a similar result is obtained when the measurement is repeated by a different method or under different conditions
Suggest how you can adapt this experiment to check if your value of \(\frac{d}{l}\) is reproducible
You are **not** required to do this experiment
Measure the length \(L\) of HJ
Use your value of \(l\) from **(c)**(i) and \(L\) from **(f)**(i) to calculate \(\frac{l}{L}\)
Calculate a value \(n\) for the refractive index of the block. Use the equation shown
[Total: 10]
In this experiment, you will investigate the deviation of a ray of light passing through a transparent block and determine a quantity called the refractive index \(n\) of the block

A student sets up a flexible track at the edge of a bench. The student investigates a metal ball as it rolls from rest down the track and travels through the air. The metal ball travels a horizontal distance \(d\) through the air and lands in a tray of sand placed on the floor
Plan an experiment to investigate how one variable affects the size of this distance \(d\)
The apparatus available includes:
· flexible track
· clamp, boss and stand to support the track
· selection of metal balls
Fig. 4.1 shows how the flexible track is supported
You are **not** required to do this investigation
In your plan:
state the **one** variable you have chosen to investigate
list any additional apparatus needed to measure this variable
· explain how to do the experiment
· state the key variables to be kept constant
· draw a table, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
· explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
